Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Story:
I stared at my phone, reading the text from Mia for the third time. “I thought we agreed on Saturday for brunch, not Sunday.” I could sense her disappointment, and my chest tightened. As her boyfriend, I knew I should call her, talk it out, and clear up the misunderstanding before it grew into something bigger. But just as I reached for my phone, a Slack notification popped up: “Hey, we’re hoping you’ll join the brainstorming session next week. Your input on the new feature would be awesome!” 

I knew the session was technically optional, but as a software developer, I felt the unspoken pressure to show up, contribute, and prove I was a team player. My manager always said collaboration was key, and I didn’t want to seem disengaged. I could already feel the tug-of-war inside me—Mia needed reassurance and attention, but my team expected commitment and creativity. My mind raced, torn between smoothing things over with Mia and stepping up at work, both roles demanding more than I felt I could give at once.
